how: Traditional visualization emerges as the most frequently appearing category in our corpus, encompassing a range of well-established and widely-used techniques for visually representing data. These techniques are characterized by their ability to effectively convey information through structured and organized visual representations, include maps, point-based visualizations, graph, text-based visualizations, matrix visualizations, and dashboards.

Narrative visualization refers to a class of techniques that integrate storytelling elements with traditional visualization methods to “communicate information in a psychologically efficient format”. These techniques support enhancing the communication of insights and engaging the audience, including various narrative visualization genres, such as comic strips, videos, animations, annotated charts, infographics, and slide shows.

Tangible visualization, also known as data physicalization, refers to techniques that map data into physical forms. hese techniques represent data through physical artifacts or their behavior, offering unique opportunities for multi-sensory engagement and embodied interaction with data.
Visual encoding maps data to visual marks and manipulates the visual properties of these marks through the use of various visual channels.
Visual effects use animation and figurative metaphors to enhance the communicative power of visualizations by adding dynamic and expressive qualities to the visual representation.
Visual relationships involve using spatial layout techniques to convey connections and hierarchies between multiple data representations.
Data operation actions involve user interactions that directly manipulate or process data based on visual perception.
Non-data actions involve user interactions that navigate, arrange, and control the visual representation of the data.
Sensory actions expand the interaction possibilities by engaging users through non-visual modalities, such as auditory and tactile channels.
Ordering involves structuring the sequence of events or facts in visualization to create a coherent narrative flow.
Messaging focuses on providing data explanations or contextual information to enhance the understanding of visualization.
Framing shapes the overall narrative style and tone of visualization, influencing how readers perceive and emotionally engage with it.
The begin of construction process, where researchers gather a diverse set of examples, case studies, or datasets relevant to their specific visualization context.
After, researchers carefully curate and filter the collected data to create a representative and manageable corpus.
The core of the process, where researchers analyze the refined corpus to identify key design patterns, choices, and dimensions.
This phase involves iterating and improving upon the initial design space based on feedback from pilot studies.
This phase involves a deeper exploration of the refined design space to uncover trends and insights that can inform future visualization design and research.
This phase involves assessing the effectiveness, usability, and impact of the design space through user studies, workshops, expert interviews, and experiments.

card_title: Vis · the taxonomy of visualization components
how: It categorizes data types into 12 subtypes Area, Bar, Circle, Diagram, Distribution, Grid and Matrix, Trees and Networks, Line, Map, Point, Table, and Text et al.

card_title: Vis · the model of composite visualization
how: It identifies five visual composition patterns for visualization components: Juxtaposition, Integration, Superimposition, Overloading, and Nesting.

card_title: Vis · the classification of chart annotation
how: It defines four types of annotation forms: Text, Shapes, Highlights, and Images, as well as four types of annotation objects: Data Items, Structural Chart Elements, Coordinate Spaces, and Prior Annotation.

card_title: Vis · the design space of narrative visualization
how: It introduces seven genres for storytelling, such as Poster and Video, and presents a set of visual narrative tactics and narrative structure tactics that facilitate narrative, such as Messaging and Interactivity.
They provide insights into narrative techniques and structures that can be applied to visualization design.
It provides frameworks and concepts to help identify design dimensions related to user interaction and user experience.
It offers principles for quantifying and communicating information effectively, which can inform visualization design.
